Chapter 10, Part 2: Distinguishing the Ten [Types of] Discernment. The ancillary discussion on the effect of separation from the cause is now complete. The original topic will now be discussed.

Among the five effects to be distinguished - the effect of karmic maturation, the effect of outflow, the effect of separation, the effect of human action, and the dominant effect - which effect is obtained by which cause among the previous six causes?
Verse:
The effect of karmic maturation is the effect of the last cause, and the dominant effect is the effect of the first cause.
The effect of outflow is the effect of the homogeneous cause, the universal cause, and so forth, and the effect of human action is the effect of the associated cause and the co-existent cause.
Discussion:

Among the five effects, the third effect of separation is not obtained by the cause of birth, therefore it is not discussed here. The remaining four effects obtained by the six causes will now be discussed.
The last cause refers to the cause of karmic maturation, because it is mentioned last in the verse on the causes.
The first effect of karmic maturation is obtained by this cause.
Some say:
Because the effect of retribution arises from the cause of retribution, it should not be called nonretribution.
This is unreasonable, because the two causes of similar status and retribution produce effects that are different.
That is, the former effect of retribution is the similar cause that produces the latter effect of retribution, which is the effect similar to the cause.
The latter effect of retribution is accomplished by prior karma. The karma that accomplishes it is called the cause of retribution.
The effect of retribution that is accomplished is the effect of retribution.
The two causes are different, and the two effects are distinguished. The classes of causes and effects are different, and there is no error of confusion.

However, the substance of the effect of retribution is like cooked food and drink. It has no superior function in producing the effect of retribution. Therefore only the unwholesome and the wholesome that is impure is the cause of retribution and is called having retribution.
The former cause refers to the efficient cause, because it is mentioned first in the verse on causes.
The latter dominant effect is obtained by this cause.
The effect of the dominant condition is called the dominant effect.
What is the dominant condition of mere nonobstruction?
Is it not said that the dominant condition is that which is not obstructive? Why is it necessary to ask?

Also, it has already been explained in the section on the efficient cause that the efficient cause also has a superior power, namely, that when visual consciousness, etc., are about to arise, the auditory, etc., have a dominant power over them, because when one hears, one immediately wishes to see.

When the various things of the receptacle world are born, the actions of sentient beings have a dominant power. There is a dominant power in the production of desirable results from good actions and undesirable results from bad actions. These dominant powers should be considered as appropriate.
Homogeneous and omnipresent causes obtain an outflow result, because the result resembles the cause and is called an outflow.
These two causes have similar characteristics in their results, and therefore, although there are two causes, there is only one result.

Concomitant and simultaneous causes obtain a result that is a human effort, because there is no human effort apart from the substance of the human being. The result obtained is called a result that is a human effort.
What does this term human effort refer to?
It refers to the power possessed by dharmas, which corresponds to the following verse:
If a result arises due to the power of that [cause], it is called the effect of human action.
However, the author of the commentary takes this term effect of human action to refer to the activity possessed by dharmas. He should have said:
Because they jointly attract one result, they are called the effect of human action.

If that is so, then there should only be the effect of human action that is immediately contiguous or separated, not that which arises simultaneously. It is not possible that within the simultaneous [cause and effect] there could be all [dharmas] jointly obtaining one effect of human action, because the self-nature does not arise due to the power of the self.
It also cannot be said that each individually attracts a result, lest the co-existent cause not be a single result.

Here, the effect of human action, human power, human ability, and the power of the human being all have no difference in meaning. Because the power of dharmas is like the effect of human action, it is called the effect of human action, just as a brave and strong person is called a lion because he resembles a lion.

Aren't the two fruits of dissimilarity and universal cause also the fruit of human effort produced immediately after? However, all dharmas produced immediately after the two causes of similarity and universal cause are either or not called the fruit of human effort. Why is it said that only co-existent and associated causes obtain the fruit of human effort, not the similar and universal causes?
Only these two causes are fully able to obtain the two fruits of human effort that arise simultaneously and immediately after, not the first two causes. Therefore, they are not mentioned.
The fruit of similarity is only similar to its own cause, and the fruit of similarity and universal cause is only similar. Therefore, those two fruits are only called similarity.
The other fruits are not similarity, because they are not obtained by the two causes.

Moreover, the fruit of human effort is stronger in the simultaneous cause. Only the co-existent and associated causes are able to obtain the simultaneous fruit of human effort. Therefore, it is said in a biased way.

Also, although homogeneous causes can obtain the immediately antecedent karmic result of the activity of the person, not all can definitely obtain it, because the final aggregates of an arhat do not have the karmic result of the activity of the person that arises immediately after them.
The two causes of co-existence and association definitely obtain the karmic result of the activity of the person, and therefore they are mentioned specifically.
Other masters say:

The productive cause, etc., also have the meaning of being able to obtain the karmic result of the activity of the person. It is not the cause of maturation, because the two karmic results of the activity of the person that arise simultaneously and immediately after it do not exist.
Other masters say:
This cause of maturation also has the distant karmic result of the activity of the person, just as the fruits reaped by a farmer.
The definite relationship between causes and effects has already been discussed. Now we will correctly discuss the distinctions in the characteristics of effects.
What are the characteristics of the effects such as maturation, etc.?
Verse:
Maturation is a neutral dharma, produced by sentient beings.
The outflow is similar to its own cause. The unfettered is the exhaustion by wisdom.
If a result arises due to the power of a cause, it is called the result of human effort.
Except for the above, conditioned dharmas are the dominant results of conditioned dharmas.
The treatise says:
Only in the case of unobstructed indeterminate dharmas is there a retribution result.
If that is so, then what is not associated with sentient beings should also be retribution.
In order to distinguish that, the text says associated with sentient beings. Because only what is associated with sentient beings has retribution.
If that is so, then among what is associated with sentient beings, the nourished and the outflow result should be retribution.

Also, in order to distinguish that, the text says arisen from what is capable of being a cause of retribution. All that is unwholesome and all that is wholesome and contaminated can cause retribution, and therefore it is called capable of being a cause of retribution. Retribution arises later from that.
It is not called capable of being a cause of retribution if it arises simultaneously or immediately after.
This is called the characteristic of the retribution result.

Is it not the case that the prior substance of retribution is the homogeneous cause of the subsequent stage of retribution, because it is the similar cause of the prior retribution? Then it should also be said that it arises from the indeterminate, because it is a similar cause. How is it said that it arises from the determinate?
There is no such fault in the case of the similar cause.

The substance of retribution is confused in its characteristics as a homogeneous cause, but the characteristics of the cause of retribution are not confused. Therefore it is said that it arises only from the determinate.
From this, it is understood that the similar cause is not a similar result, because the similar result is confused with the cause in its characteristics.

If the result of retribution is not confused with the cause in its characteristics, and because it arises from action, why is it not said that the result of retribution of that which is not a sentient being also arises from action?
This should not be criticized, because the result obtained by action that is not shared is called retribution.
Why is this?

That which is not a sentient being is not only the result obtained by action that is not shared, because other sentient beings can experience together the results of dharmas that are not sentient beings.

Is it not the case that the abode of the great Brahma is not a result of the karma of a single being, and should it not be said that it is the result of the karma of many beings? Why do you say that it is not?
There is an opinion that
the abode of the great Brahma is born of the dominant power of the karma of all Brahmas.
There is another opinion that
the abode of the great Brahma is not a result common to all beings, because it is possible that others can enjoy it as long as it is not destroyed.
How can one thing be the result of the common karma of innumerable beings?
Havenâ€™t we already said that it is because others can enjoy it?
If the result of non-common karma is not attracted by common karma, it should perish when the retribution is exhausted.
Also, in the world, when the king dies, the country that he ruled still continues to exist.
If the country that the king rules is attracted by the karma of the king alone and not by the common karma of other beings, others should not be able to enjoy it.

If it were not the case that nonliving things are produced by the individual karma of sentient beings, then the houses, gardens, ponds, and so forth that sentient beings inhabit would each be different.
But this is not so, and therefore we know that a single thing is produced by the common karma of innumerable sentient beings.

But since the substance of karma is of various kinds, it cannot produce a result that is not of various kinds. How can you say that innumerable sentient beings with many different karmas produce a single nonliving thing?
There is no such error, because, just as sprouts, etc., are considered to be one because they are the results of similar causes.

That is, even though sprouts, etc., are produced by the power of causes such as earth, water, fire, time, space, human effort, and manure, they are considered to be one because they are the results of similar causes. They are not considered to be many because of the many causes such as earth.
In the same way, nonliving things are considered to be one because they are the results of similar causes. They are not considered to be many because of the many causes of innumerable karmas.
Also, you see that various actions do not produce various results. Why do you not admit that various actions do not produce non-various results?
What is the power of action in producing non-sentient results?
Action is the efficient cause of those results, as has been explained previously.
Having thus explained the characteristics of the result of retribution, the characteristics of the result of similar outflow will now be explained.
A dharma that is similar to its own cause is called the result of similar outflow, i.e., similar to the two causes of similar species and universal cause.
Just as the causes of similar species are good, defiled, and indeterminate, their results of similar outflow are also like this.
Just as the universal cause is only defiled, its result of similar outflow is also like this.

Isnâ€™t the nature of the result of direct utilization that arises simultaneously also similar to its own cause? How can it be said that a result of similar outflow is a dharma similar to its own cause?

There is no result of similar outflow that is not similar to its own cause, but there is a result of direct utilization that differs from its own cause. Therefore, a result of similar outflow is called a dharma similar to its own cause, and there is definitely no error in confusing it with the result of direct utilization.
Arenâ€™t there also homogeneous results that are caused by homogeneous causes? For example, the omnipresent cause uses dharmas of other categories as homogeneous results.

The homogeneous results of other categories and the causes of oneâ€™s own category are the same in being defiled. They are not dissimilar. The nature of the dominant result is also different from the cause. Therefore the result is not necessarily similar to the cause.
Another interpretation of the statement that the result is similar to the cause is that the result is similar to the cause in two ways:
first, in substance, and second, in species.
Substance refers to feeling, conceptualization, etc.

Species refers to good, defilement, etc.ğŸ”½If the dominant result occurs simultaneously with its cause, the species is the same, but the substance is necessarily different, because feeling is not the same as volition, etc.
If the dominant result occurs subsequent to its cause, the substance and species may be different, and for that reason it cannot be said that the result is similar to the cause.

If the nature of the effect of similar cause is necessarily similar to its cause, then there are some that are similar to their cause, but only the effect of similar cause is definitely similar to its cause. Therefore, there is no error in the expression â€œsimilar to its cause.â€
If the effect of similar cause is also the effect of universal cause, why is it not admitted that this is the same as the cause of similar class?
In fact, it is the cause of similar class with regard to its effect in its own class. If it is considered with regard to other classes, it is only universal cause, not cause of similar class.
However, with regard to dharmas that are not universal, each is only the cause of similar class with regard to its own class, according to its nature and species.
With regard to other classes, universal dharmas are only universal cause, because they are the same as defiled species.

With regard to its own class, it is both causes. Therefore, although the effect of similar cause is also the effect of universal cause, it cannot be admitted that universal cause is the same as the cause of similar class.
The characteristics of the effect of similar cause have been discussed. The characteristics of the effect of separation will now be discussed.
The name of the effect of separation is due to the extinction of dharmas by means of wisdom.

Because it is extinguished, it is called extinction. Because it is selected, it is called wisdom. Extinction that is selected is called the effect of separation, because one is separated from all bonds through selecting it as a cause and realizing this extinction. Therefore, it is called an effect.
Thus the characteristics of the effect of separation have been explained. The characteristics of the effect of human action will now be discussed.
If a dharma is produced by the power of another dharma, then this dharma is called the effect of human action. There are four kinds of this effect:
simultaneous, immediate, remote, and unarisen, as explained above.
Simultaneous means that they are produced by the power of mutual causality at the same time.

Immediate means that they are produced by the power of the cause of the preceding moment in the next moment, such as the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors with regard to suffering produced by the supreme worldly state.
Remote means that they are produced by the power of the cause of successive moments at a distant time, such as the farmers, etc., with regard to the grains, wheat, etc.
Unarisen means nirvÄá¹‡a, because it is obtained by the power of the uninterrupted path.
Since it is not produced, how can it be said that it is called the effect of human effort because it is produced by power?
It is now seen that the term â€œproductionâ€ is also used for obtaining, as in the statement, â€œMy wealth is produced,â€ which means â€œI have obtained wealth.â€
The cessation resulting from discrimination that is realized by the path of noninterruption that eliminates the propensities is called the effect of separation and the effect of human effort.

If the path of noninterruption does not eliminate the propensities and one realizes again the cessation resulting from discrimination that was previously realized, this cessation is not the effect of separation but only the effect of human effort.

When a person who has not yet completely eliminated the passions of the realm of desire enters the path of insight, the cessation resulting from discrimination that is realized by the perseverance for the knowledge of the dharma of suffering that eliminates ten propensities is called the effect of separation and the effect of human effort.

When a person who has already completely eliminated the passions of the realm of desire enters the path of insight, the perseverance for the knowledge of the dharma of suffering does not eliminate the propensities and realizes the previously attained cessation resulting from discrimination. This cessation is not the effect of separation, because it was previously separated from the propensities;
This is the effect of conscious effort, because by the power of this patience one produces other acquisitions and realizes again.

If one has already separated from desire of the realm of desire, when one enters the path of insight, the patience that is knowledge of the law with regard to suffering eliminates ten propensities to mistakenly grasp, and there is elimination of the truth of the path that is already existent and newly acquired, as the case may be. The same is true of the patience that is knowledge of the law with regard to the path.

If one has not yet separated from desire, or has separated from it, or has separated from part of it, when one enters the path of insight, one completely eliminates or partially eliminates or does not eliminate the eight propensities to mistakenly grasp, and one acquires the elimination of the truth of the path that is already existent and newly acquired and that is both already existent and newly acquired, as the case may be. The same is true of the patience that is knowledge of the law with regard to the path.

If one has not yet separated from desire of the realm of form and of the formless realm, when one enters the path of insight, the patience that is subsequent knowledge with regard to suffering eliminates the eighteen propensities to mistakenly grasp of the realms of form and of the formless realm, and the elimination of the truth of the path that is acquired is called the effect of separation and the effect of conscious effort.

If one has already separated from attachment to the form and formless realms and enters the path of insight, then the perseverance for subsequent knowledge with regard to the truth of suffering eliminates or does not eliminate the eighteen propensities of the form and formless realms, and one realizes or does not realize the cessation resulting from the elimination of those propensities. There is a new cessation and an original cessation, and there is a second fruit and a first fruit, respectively.

In the same way, up to the perseverance for the knowledge of the path, if one has not yet separated from attachment to the form and formless realms or has already separated from part of it, then one completely eliminates or partially eliminates or does not eliminate the fourteen propensities of the form and formless realms, and one realizes or does not realize the cessation resulting from the elimination of those propensities. There is a new cessation and an original cessation, and there are two fruits and two fruits and one fruit, respectively. The meaning is explained as above.
In the path of cultivation, the various paths of immediate succession each correspond to their meaning, and one should consider them in the same way.
In this way, we have explained the characteristics of the fruit of separation. The characteristics of the dominant fruit will now be explained.
All conditioned dharmas, excluding those that arise before, are the dominant fruit of the remaining conditioned dharmas. There is no small fruit that arises before its cause.
If the fruit arises before the cause, what fault is there?
If the effect of a future dharma has already arisen, then the future has already performed its function and should not arise again, because it is without function.
That which has not previously arisen cannot have cessation. Because it has neither arising nor cessation, conditioned forces should be permanent.
If it is said that this should be like a dharma that does not arise, which, although it has neither arising nor cessation, is not permanent,
this refutation is not valid. Because we see that its class has arising and cessation, it can be said that a dharma that does not arise is impermanent.
If a conditioned force originally has neither arising nor cessation, how can it be said that its substance is not permanent?
Therefore this is not a valid refutation.
How should one understand the difference between the two results, the result of the dominant condition and the result of the human effort?

Because there is a difference in the one who acts and the one who experiences, one should understand the difference. The name result of the human effort is only in reference to the one who acts, and the name result of the dominant condition is in reference to the one who experiences.

For example, grains such as rice and wheat are called the result of the human effort in reference to farmers, because they are born from their power, and they are also the result of the dominant condition, because the farmers experience them.
The only one that is the dominant fruit is the fruit of retribution, because it is not born from the power of the action but is experienced by the action.
The fruit of the craftsman and the fruit of the owner are like the fruit of the master.
The remaining fruits are similar to these.
In the above six causes, in what state do they take a fruit and give a fruit?
The verse states:
The five take a fruit only in the present; two give a fruit in the same way.
The past and present give two causes; one gives only in the past.
The treatise states:
The five causes take a fruit only in the present. They definitely do not take a fruit in the past, because they have already taken it.
They also do not take a fruit in the future, because they have no function.

The meaning of taking a fruit is that of attracting, that is, attracting the future to cause its arising, etc. It can be the seed of a homogeneous category. In a heterogeneous category, it is by the same fruit. In a category that is not the same fruit, it is by the same nature. In a heterogeneous category, it is by having this as the continuity of one's own aggregate.
Therefore all are called â€œattracting.â€ This attracting is called â€œtaking a fruit.â€
This function of taking a fruit exists only in the present and not in the past or future. Only this can be called the activity of conditioned dharmas.
Among the six causes, which cause is excluded, and why is it said that only five causes take a fruit in the present?
Among the six causes, the efficient cause is excluded.
For what reason is this efficient cause excluded?
Other masters say:
This efficient cause has no fixed time in taking a fruit or giving a fruit, therefore it is not distinguished in taking or giving.
Their explanation is unreasonable.
Why is it unreasonable?
This cause has no taking of a fruit that is not in the present.
Also, it is not the case that there is giving without taking. How can it be said that there is no fixed time?

However, the active cause that takes a result is definitely only in the present. It should be like the two causes of similar type and universal, which only do not take or give an enhanced result. Therefore, this is not discussed.
Isn't it that the function of this cause in taking a result also extends to the past? How can it be said that the one who takes a result is definitely only in the present?
Therefore, the original treatise says:
Past dharmas serve as the equal and immediate condition to give rise to two minds.
If the mind that emerges from the attainment of non-perception or the attainment of cessation takes the present as the one that takes, then the two attainments would never appear again.
Moreover, there is no meaning of giving without taking. Therefore, taking a result also extends to the past.
There is no such thing. The mind that enters the two attainments only in the present can take the result of the two attainments and the mind that emerges from them.
However, since the two attainments are what is definitely sought, they must be produced first;
Because of this obstruction, the mind emerging from samÄdhi does not arise immediately after the mind entering samÄdhi. This meaning will be further distinguished later.
Therefore, what was said above, that this cause takes its effect only in the present,
and that there is no giving without taking, is extremely well established.
However, the VaibhÄá¹£ikas have the following explanation:
The efficient cause takes its effect and gives its effect both in the past and present.
This is not reasonable, because a dharma in the present is like the two causes of homogeneous and omnipresent, which collectively take the future as their own effect.
The simultaneous and associated causes are also like this, only in the present, because these two causes take their effects and give their effects necessarily at the same time.
The two causes of homogeneous and omnipresent give their effects both in the past and present.
The efficient cause among the various causes that have effects should be explained in the same way.
However, not all of them have effects, so this is not discussed.
The two causes similar and karmic retribution and omnipresent and consequence can be so in the past, but how can they be so in the present?
They take and give an effect of similar kind, because an effect of similar kind arises immediately after them.
That is, when these two causes have an effect of similar kind that arises immediately after them, they take and give that effect in the present.
When that effect has already arisen and the cause has already perished and become past, it is said that the effect has been taken and given.

If these two causes perish and reach the past, and the effect of similar kind only reaches the state of being born, then these two causes first take the effect that is about to be born and now give it.
As for giving an effect, it means that these causes are just giving it power to make it be born, etc. The efficient cause is just in the present.
That dominant effect has already been born in the present, just as the eye faculty, etc., as an efficient cause, gives rise to eye consciousness, etc.

All dominant effects have an immediate arising, just as the supreme worldly dharmas, etc., as an efficient cause, give rise to the forbearance of the knowledge of the dharmas of suffering, etc., as dominant effects.

There is a case of remote production, such as the roots of good that are favorable to liberation, etc., which are the efficient cause of the knowledge of the awareness of the exhaustion of all the asravas of the three vehicles, etc., and are the dominant result.
There are times when good homogeneous causes take a result but do not give a result. Four sentences are possible.
The first sentence refers to the acquisition that is the last to be eliminated when one eliminates the roots of good.
The second sentence refers to the acquisition that is the first to be obtained when one restores the roots of good.
The ÅšÄstra master makes a mistake here and says,
It should be said that at that time, the one who restores obtains the prior.
We examine this statement and it is not reasonable.
Why is this?

It is not only the acquisition that is the last to be eliminated in the state of elimination that takes the result of homogeneous cause that is obtained at the time of restoration, because the previously eliminated acquisitions also take the result of homogeneous cause that is obtained at the time of restoration.

How is it that the many acquisitions of the prior state are the homogeneous cause, all taking the present acquisition, but at the present time it is only said that the last one of the moments of acquisition in the state of elimination gives the result of the present acquisition?
Therefore, the original text should be considered correct.
The third case refers to those who have not severed wholesome roots in the remaining states.
The fourth case refers to excluding the above characteristics.
Moreover, in the similar causes of unwholesome [dharmas], there are also four cases.
The first case refers to when one is free from craving, the last [wholesome dharma] that is abandoned.
The second case refers to when one regresses from being free from craving, the first [wholesome dharma] that is obtained.
The ÅšÄstra master also says this:
It should be said that at that time, the previously obtained [wholesome dharmas] of the regressor are [the similar causes].
Now, examining his statement, the principle is also not so, because there is the above-mentioned fault.
The third case refers to those who have not yet become free from craving in the remaining states.
The fourth case refers to excluding the above characteristics.

In the similar causes of obscured and neutral [dharmas], there are also four cases, which should be explained according to reason at the time of obtaining [obscured and neutral dharmas] by arhats, at the time of regression, and in the remaining states where they have not yet been obtained.
As for the homogeneous cause of non-defiled and non-defined dharmas, there is a subsequent phrase, which means that when it gives forth a fruit, it must also take a fruit.

Because the non-defiled and non-defined dharmas as homogeneous causes continue in a series until nirvana, sometimes they take a fruit but do not give forth a fruit, that is, the final aggregates of an arhat, in terms of the distinctions of moments with objects.
The homogeneous cause of good dharmas should be made into four sentences.
The first sentence is, for example, a defiled or non-defined mind arising immediately after a good mind.
The second sentence is the opposite of the above.
The third sentence is, for example, a good mind arising immediately after a good mind.
The fourth sentence is, for example, excluding the above characteristics.
The four sentences should be applied in the same way to bad minds, etc., as appropriate.

It should be explained by analogy that the cause of retribution only gives forth its fruit in the past, because the fruit of retribution is neither simultaneous with nor immediately contiguous to its cause.
Masters of the West say that there are nine fruits, establishing four fruits apart from the previous five fruits:
The first is the result of added effort, which is like the result of the knowledge of non-arising, etc., which is the distant result of impurity, etc.ğŸ”½ğŸ”½

The second is the result of establishment, which is like the water wheel being the result of the wind wheel, and so on up to grass, etc., being the result of the great earth. All established dharmas should be known as being the results of that which establishes them.

The third is the result of combination, which is like sprouts, etc., being the result of time, earth, water, seeds, etc., and eye consciousness, etc., being the result of eye, form, light, and attention, etc.
The fourth is the result of cultivation, which is like the mind of transformation, etc., being the result of the various meditations.
These four results are all included in the results of human effort and predominance. For this reason, it is said that there are only five results.
Having discussed causes and results, we should further investigate:
How many causes produce these dharmas?
Here, dharmas are generally of four kinds: defiled dharmas, dharmas born of retribution,
the first pure dharmas, and the remaining dharmas.
What are the remaining dharmas?
They are those other than those born of retribution.
The remaining neutral dharmas, excluding the first pure dharmas, are the remaining wholesome dharmas.
As for these four dharmas, the verse says:ğŸ”½Defiled and karmically mature dharmas, the remaining first holy dharmas, in order,
Exclude karmically mature, universal, and two similar causes, and the remaining are born.
These are called mind and mental factors. The remaining exclude the associated.
The treatise says:
All defiled dharmas, excluding the karmically mature cause, are born from the remaining five causes, because the dharmas born from the karmically mature cause are not defiled.
Karmically mature dharmas, excluding the universal cause, are born from the remaining five causes, because the dharmas born from the universal cause are only defiled.

The remaining dharmas, excluding both the karmically mature and universal causes, are born from the remaining four causes, because the remaining dharmas are not of the karmically mature nature and are not defiled.
The first pure dharmas, excluding the similar cause.
The word and is used to show that the karmically mature and universal causes are also excluded.
The remaining three are born from causes, because the first pure dharmas have no prior similar dharmas, and because they are good.
Other masters say:
Here it should be said that defiled dharmas are born from only four causes.
Why is this?
Because the substance of the cause of universal permeation is separate from the cause of similar type and has no other nature.
Their words are unreasonable.
Why is this?
If they do not mention the cause of universal permeation, they do not explain the cause of defilement in other classes.
If they do not mention the cause of similar type, they do not explain the cause of dharmas that are not universally permeating and the cause of the possession of universal permeation.

However, in reality, craving, etc., are the cause of craving, etc., and possession is born by means of the cause of possession. Therefore it is reasonable to say that defiled dharmas, excluding the cause of retribution, are born from the remaining five causes.
What are these four dharmas that are said to be born from causes?
You should know that they are only mind and mental activities.
If this is so, how many causes do the remaining dharmas, the four dharmas of non-associated compositional factors and form, arise from?

Just as the mind and mental factors arise from causes other than the associated cause, one should know that the remaining dharmas arise from four, three, two, or the remaining causes.ğŸ”½That is to say, defiled form and non-associated compositional factors, like the mind and mental factors, arise from four causes other than the cause of karmic maturation and other than the associated cause.

Form that is karmically matured and non-associated compositional factors, like the mind and mental factors, arise from four causes other than the cause of universal occurrence and other than the associated cause.

Moreover, one should contemplate:
The distinctions of these six causes in terms of form, non-form, etc.

Moreover, among the six causes, the universal cause is included in the three realms of mind, mental objects, and mental consciousness. The various characteristics of these causes and effects cannot be fully understood without omniscience. Following the path of our own enlightened wisdom, we have extensively discussed their characteristics in the section on causes and effects.
In order to clarify and contemplate the various conditions,
what are the various conditions?
The verse states:
It is said there are four kinds of conditions, with causal conditions having the nature of the five causes,
The immediately preceding condition is not subsequent, and the mind and mental factors have already arisen.
The objective condition is all dharmas, and the dominant condition is the enabling cause.
The treatise states:
Where is this taught?
It is taught in the sutras.

As taught in the sutras, there are four kinds of conditional natures, namely the causal condition nature, the immediately preceding condition nature, the objective condition nature, and the dominant condition nature.
Among them, the conditional natures are precisely the four conditions, just as the four kinds of abodes are the natures of the abodes. The word nature is used to indicate the types.

The mind discriminates various conditions, and according to the distinctions of events, there are innumerable natures. However, when their meanings are summarized, they are all included within the four types of conditions, because all conditions do not exceed these natures.
Among the six causes, excluding the enabling cause, the remaining five causes are the nature of causal conditions.

What are causal conditions?

includes all dharmas. According to the differences in events, there are many kinds of distinctions.

the first is the common cause, and the second is the uncommon cause.

the first is the proximate cause, and the second is the remote cause.

the first is the cause arising previously, and the second is the cause arising simultaneously.
There are two other kinds:
the first is the cause of the continuity of self and others, and the second is the cause that is not sentient.

Although the nature of all dharmas is originally existent and not nonexistent, the accomplishment of function necessarily depends on the power of causes, just as the form of all created dharmas is originally not nonexistent, but the accomplishment of function necessarily depends on the primary elements.
Among the causes, the most excellent ones are the five causes.

Just as the five [sense bases] do not exist for one who has attained the cause of form, there is no conditioned dharma that is accomplished without a cause, just as a weak person cannot stand up by himself.
Because of this meaning, a verse is spoken:

The causes of dharmas are numerous and subtle, difficult to understand. The world is confused and then says they are completely without causes.
However, the elder says that the nature of conditions is the old following realm, which is the causal nature that can be passed on from one to another in the continuity of sentient beings.

One should know that such a person's good dharmas are hidden and evil dharmas appear, but there are still wholesome roots that accompany them and have not been cut off.
Because they have not been cut off, from these wholesome roots there is still the meaning of being able to give rise to other wholesome roots.

This is also refuted in the same way as the theory of seeds held by the master of the sutras. The old homogeneous character is the same as those seeds, only the names are different.

Now, taking advantage of the opportunity, we will further refute the differences in names and meanings held by the other party. All continuities that are causes of transformation have substance that can be obtained, like form, feeling, etc.
If the old homogeneous character is a continuity that is the cause of transformation, it should be like form, etc., and have substance that can be obtained.
What is its characteristic?

Therefore, if it exists, it should be one kind among the natures of the five aggregates such as form.
Or they should say:

However, its substance exists and can be established, so there is only the word but no real substance.

This old homogeneous character cannot be said to have a substance, but it can be said that it is the six sense bases perfumed by karma and afflictions that give rise to the fruits of other lives.
This character is not only indescribable in substance, but the attachment to its existence contradicts reason.
It cannot be established that what is indescribable in substance exists, because the provisional existence of the person and pots, etc. can be said to be without a separate substance.

If the real existence of dharmas such as form, feeling, etc. can each be said to have a separate substance, then the old homogeneous character cannot be said to exist, just like the person and pots, etc. which are provisionally existent, nor can it be said to be really existent like dharmas such as form. Therefore, one should not attach to it as existent.
If that is so, how can it be grasped as a causal condition?

What do they mean by the six sense bases perfumed by action and the passions and that produce results in a subsequent life?

Do they mean the six sense bases that are born and perish together with action and the passions, or do they mean those that are born in a continuous series after that, or do they mean those that immediately produce retribution?
If the six sense bases that are born together with action and the passions can produce results, then the later six sense bases will be unable to produce results.
If the former are able to produce results, why not the latter?
Only action and the passions would have the ability to produce results, so why insist that the six sense bases produce results in a subsequent life?

Also, they should not insist that the eyes, etc., are assisting causes that are born together with action and the passions, because the blind, etc., are born in a subsequent life with eyes, ears, etc., that are born from causes of action and the passions.
Also, they admit that causes and results may be separated by a long time, so why insist that these are old seeds?

If the six sense bases in the subsequent continuum are able to produce effects, they are not at all associated with karma and afflictions. How can they be perfumed by them and become the seeds of the karmic forces?
There is no meaning of association between existence and nonexistence.
Isn't it the case that cause and effect can be associated, because they are the same as that and become conditions for it?

The words the same as that are not logically appropriate, because the word that refers to its characteristics. It should be said that this characteristic is the same as that. However, in this brief explanation, the word this characteristic is omitted.
This karma and affliction are of a different kind from the six sense bases in the subsequent continuum. How can this characteristic be the same as that?
How can they be associated and become the nature of conditions?

Or perhaps they think that the six sense bases that are about to cease, along with the karmic actions and afflictions, have the same characteristics as the subsequent six sense bases, and that this makes them conditions. This also is unreasonable, because the characteristics of the previous six sense bases at the time of their cessation do not yet exist in the subsequent entity. Since the subsequent entity does not yet exist, its characteristics also do not exist. How can there be a similarity of characteristics that makes them become conditions?
Therefore what they say is mere empty words.
If they say that the term characteristics refers to what will exist, just as the world says to cook rice and to grind flour, because that will exist in the future,

If they are ultimately nonexistent, like empty flowers, then the analogy is not established as the same as the thesis.
If according to the conventional they are cooking and grinding, then on this basis one can say to cook rice and to grind flour.
It is not possible for a dharma to be the same as nonexistence, so this analogy has no power to prove the thesis.
However, this rice and flour do not have the name existing, because rice and flour that are presently well-known exist. Observing this, one can say that Devadatta is the same as this.
The analogy of cooking rice and grinding flour is not so, so it is not appropriate.

Moreover, after the cooked rice and ground flour are finished, the continuity of the rice and flour that are being prepared still exists. The similarity between the two is both present and can be obtained.

When the six sense bases of the subsequent moment reach the time of having arisen, at that time the six sense bases of the previous moment do not exist. Therefore, it cannot be said that the two are the same.

Because the two states of the subsequent [six sense bases] not having arisen and having arisen cannot both be said to be the same as the previous [six sense bases], the analogy given is not the same as the dharma [being proven].

Even if you admit that the rice cake is the future name, the analogy is still not correct, because the six sense bases that arise from the previous moment of consciousness do not accompany action and the passions, and the six sense bases that arise from action and the passions as assisting conditions do not have different characteristics, because they are not cause and effect. How can you say that they have the power to make the future six sense bases become conditions?

Therefore you cannot say that the six sense bases that accompany action and the passions are superior to the previous six sense bases and that they are the same as the future ones and make them become the nature of conditions.

Therefore, if you say that the previous six sense bases that perish can still generate the later similar six sense bases, and action and the passions that perish can still generate later similar action and passions, then you can say that there is a future name and that there is the meaning of similarity.

If the six sense bases that are the cause of retribution are only born from uninterrupted karma, then there would be no karma whose results are experienced in a subsequent life, because only the uninterrupted cause produces retribution.
This error does not exist, because the uninterrupted and the proximate successively attract results, just as flowers, seeds, etc., successively attract the production of results.

Therefore, the dharmas and the example do not correspond.
Also, you do not admit that karma and the passions perfume the six sense bases that are born with them, because you do not admit that cause and effect can exist simultaneously.
How can the six sense bases that are perfumed by karma and the passions arise later without any other conditions?
Therefore your theory is not well established.

That is, I admit that there is a simultaneous cause, and therefore I can use this as a metaphor.
But you do not admit this, so how can you say that it is like a seed perfumed by manure and soil?

How can you say that the six sense bases are the perfuming cause?
Seeds do not produce sprouts of the same substance as the manure, because the manure is not the seed. Therefore the six sense bases are like seeds.
Because the six sense bases are perfumed by karma and the passions, they produce the matured effect of the six sense bases.
This is not reasonable, because the subsequent six sense bases are not said to be the cause of the prior six sense bases.

Since the class does not exist, what dharma does the later continuation of the roots of goodness have as a cause?

After this root of goodness, the other roots of goodness will definitely arise again.

The substance of this old following realm cannot be spoken of.

If there are many kinds of mind-realms following in one mind, why does only one kind of mind arise later from this multitude of mind-realms?
Moreover, at one time, all the bases, objects, and conditions for the arising of consciousness are present, why do they not arise simultaneously?
Each moment of the basis, etc. has the meaning of being able to give rise to all consciousness, what dharma obstructs it?

However, all faculties are not shared. In this way, what principle can the elder use to refute the error of many consciousnesses arising simultaneously based on one faculty or many faculties in one life-continuum?
Therefore, the old theory of the elements of consciousness is not well-said.

Moreover, the elder and others only hold that all dharmas arise from the immediately preceding condition. Isn't it that the great master's explanation of the nature of causes and conditions becomes useless, because the power of the immediately preceding condition is sufficient to accomplish the cause on which all dharmas arise, so what is the trouble of further explaining causes and conditions?
Although he explains:
The meaning of the power of the immediately preceding condition and the power of the cause of arising are different, but they both have efficacy in the dharma of arising.

But there is no real principle, only empty words. It is only because of the power of the realm that there is uninterrupted abiding. Apart from the power of the mind and so forth as the immediately antecedent condition, one cannot say that there is a separate function of the condition as cause.
Moreover, the Sthavira holds that even though the substance of dharmas is destroyed after kalpas, its own continuity is transmitted in succession and still serves as the nature of cause.
Now, observing that dharma, it is only able to serve as a condition, giving rise to one's own mind and falsely imagining joy.
It is not really able to serve as a cause for the arising of dharmas.
Why is this?

If there is a substance of dharmas that is destroyed after kalpas and still able to serve as a cause, then that as a cause is sufficient to give rise to dharmas. Why bother to falsely construct the realm as a cause?

Moreover, if that dharma, even though without substance, is able to serve as a cause to give rise to the dharma that is produced, then one would have to admit that the daughters of barren women are also able to serve as causes to give rise to other children.

If you say that the substance of the cause exists previously and does not exist now, and that the daughters of a stone woman existed previously and exist now, then the dharmas would not be conditions as cause, because when the cause exists previously, the effect does not yet exist, and when the effect exists now, the substance of the cause does not exist. Therefore it is said that conditions as cause definitely have no function.

If the Sthavira admits that only a single continuum definitely can be a condition as cause, how can he admit that good and bad dharmas are conditions as cause that produce morally neutral karmic results?
It is not possible for good and bad dharmas to be conditions as cause that produce a morally neutral dharma, because the continuum is different.
If good and bad dharmas immediately produce a morally neutral karmic result, then you must explain why.
How can good and bad dharmas be conditions as cause that produce a morally neutral karmic result?

If you say that the morally neutral perfumes good and bad dharmas, and therefore good and bad dharmas are causes of the morally neutral, this is also unreasonable, because as we have already discussed many times, the words perfume have no real meaning.
Moreover, how can good and bad dharmas be causes as karmic results of the morally neutral because they are perfumed by the morally neutral?
If you say that the retribution perfumed by the prior action is the cause of the subsequent retribution, then the retribution would be the cause of retribution.

If the retribution is born from good and bad dharmas as its cause, and you say that in this case there is no function of causal condition but only the category of dominant condition, this is not reasonable.
Why is this?
If good and bad dharmas as causes can attract and produce that retribution, why are they not causes of that retribution?
Moreover, what they say contradicts the holy teachings, as a sutra says:
This cause and condition leads those sentient beings to be born in hell, etc.
It also says:
The eyes, etc. have karma as their cause.
It also says:
All births have karma as their cause, etc.
Here the elder gives this explanation:
Since dominant conditions do not go beyond the nature of causes, what I say is well established.
This is also unreasonable, because apart from causal conditions, the sutras separately speak of dominant conditions.
Also, it has never been said that the dominant condition is the same as the causal condition. That is, no scripture says:
The dominant condition is the causal condition.
